title: Before 1 October 2020, will the European Council decide to open accession negotiations with Albania and/or North Macedonia?
possible_answers: Yes, both Albania and North Macedonia
correct_answer: Yes, both Albania and North Macedonia
preds: Recent introduction to NATO of North Macedonia will make EC membership more palatable.

Not clear why this hasn’t been resolved yet. The European Council decided to open accession negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia on Thursday night, meaning that the question should now immediately be resolved and backdated to Thursday night. "Leaders endorsed the Council conclusions of 25 March 2020 on enlargement and stabilisation and association process." https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/2020/03/26/ These conclusions were as follows:  "In light of the progress achieved on reforms and the fulfilment of the conditions set
unanimously by the Council in June 2018, the Council, subject to endorsement by the
European Council members, decides to open accession negotiations with the Republic of
North Macedonia." and:  "In light of the progress achieved on reforms and the fulfilment of the conditions set
unanimously by the Council in June 2018, the Council, subject to endorsement by the
European Council members, decides to open accession negotiations with the Republic of
Albania." https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-7002-2020-INIT/en/pdf Here's an article on it: https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/03/26/world/europe/ap-eu-europe-enlargement.html “In the midst of the Coronavirus crisis, the European Union decided to open accession talks with North Macedonia and Albania.“ https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage/76696/accession-talks-albania-and-north-macedonia-and-eu’s-commitment-western-balkans_en

From the Economist...
“ A video conference of EU ministers will today give a green light to negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia on joining the bloc. Last October France led a group of countries that prevented this, but adjustments to the accession process have satisfied them that it can now go ahead. More delays are possible. The European Commission first recommended that North Macedonia begin talks 11 years ago. Albania’s green light will come with all sorts of conditions. On March 17th Aleksandar Vucic, the president of Serbia, the biggest of the six western Balkan countries hoping to join the EU, lambasted the bloc for its lack of help with the spread of covid-19 and appealed to “our Chinese brothers” instead. European solidarity was just a “fairy tale”, he claimed. The challenge for the EU is to breathe life back into the accession process—and not let it wither and die, as has happened with Turkey.”
The EU moves in mysterious ways.

flipping this around a bit. Keeping my no probability almost the same, but I wonder if a compromise could be reached at Zagreb in May where North Macedonia gets a go-ahead and Albania doesn't. I hadn't realized that the Albanian opposition boycotted the last set of local elections in 2019 due to alleged vote-buying by the government, and OSCE involved to try and ensure fair elections in 2021. Albania's corruption issues have of course long been well-known, for all that the Commission tries to gloss over them. These two countries have always been considered together, but from the perspective of member states, it's not obvious why they should be, and I think to enlargement skeptics (like France) then North Macedonia probably looks like a much more credible European partner at this point in time, as well as a nation less likely to lead to another deeply unpopular wave of westward migration (as happened when Bulgaria and Romania joined.

"The Commission is now expected to present updates on the reform process in Albania and the Republic of North Macedonia. The presidency’s intention is to pave the way, on the basis of those updates and the revised methodology, for an informed and comprehensive discussion with a view to a positive decision on those two countries. Andreja Metelko-Zgombić, Croatian State Secretary for European Affairs"

The EU has enough problems to deal with and announcing negotiations will encourage populist movements.

The EU has too much on with the Brexit negotiations at the moment. You would also expect the Coronavirus saga to carry on deep into the year. With countries already considering shutting their borders, this would be unwise. The EU would be unwise to open up the EU to yet more eastern bloc countries whilst anti EU sentiment is on the rise across Europe, immigration consistently proving a key factor. Expect the EUs expansion project to scale back until at least brexit has played out. With that in mind, a small chance for both, but the most likely outcome is no

With the exception of Greece and Croatia, nations rarely ever join the EU alone; they are almost exclusively groups (https://europa.eu/european-union/about-eu/countries_en#tab-0-1). Currently, there are 5 candidate countries: North Macedonia, Albania, Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey (https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/11/14/north-macedonia-wont-be-joining-anytime-soon-did-eu-lose-its-peak-leverage/). Montenegro and Serbia are already having their talks (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-balkans/french-change-of-tone-boosts-balkan-states-hopes-of-joining-eu-idUSKBN1ZZ1JY) and it is highly unlikely that Turkey will see any real progress given its actions in recent years. Thus, this is an all or nothing question. Their fates are intertwined. One of the biggest issues was France's hesitance with how the EU admits new states, an issue that was recently been addressed (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-balkans/french-change-of-tone-boosts-balkan-states-hopes-of-joining-eu-idUSKBN1ZZ1JY). While EU expansion of membership has always been a rather lower priority for the EU, these rule changes, as well as the inevitable fallout from Brexit, increases the likelihood of membership. This is because the EU will want to appear strong by increasing its membership and showing that it is still a savvy regional organization. Formerly known as Macedonia, North Macedonia has had a series of issues, including its original name. The original name was a point of major contention with Greece, an EU member, so last February, the name was changed. This name seems to be here to stay as one prominent politician was fired for merely using the old name (https://www.haaretz.com/world-news/europe/.premium-north-macedonia-s-first-jewish-minister-fired-after-using-country-s-old-name-1.8561541). It is clear that North Macedonia wants membership. The nation has also one praise for shifting toward solar energy by the EU (https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/north-macedonia-wins-eu-praise-for-pioneering-coal-to-solar-shift/). Albania, meanwhile, is also very interested in joining the EU (https://atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/albania-still-committed-to-eu-membership-pm-says/). The corruption and crime reforms needed to win over France, the Netherlands and Denmark have been implemented and are seen as being effective (https://www.rferl.org/a/eu-s-enlargement-chief-very-encouraged-by-reforms-in-north-macedonia-albania/30441611.html). Albanian membership also seems less controversial as it does not have a naming issue. Since the Netherland and Denmark support Macron, winning over France, which is what has happened in recent weeks, is all Albania and North Macedonia needs to do (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-balkans/french-change-of-tone-boosts-balkan-states-hopes-of-joining-eu-idUSKBN1ZZ1JY). The two states also already use the EU for financial support through the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance, meaning that money is not an issue for their membership (https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/qanda_20_182). All in all, it seems that the likelihood of the two nations beginning negotiations seems high, though it is always good to err on the side of caution, so we will play it safe with the 66% for now and adjust as needed.

At the moment, it seems relatively likely that accession talks with Albania and North Macedonia will begin by October.  The EC is working address Macron’s concerns regarding the EU’s enlargement process, and plans to present a proposal in late February to which Macron has already reacted somewhat positively.  France is the most vocal opponent of both countries’ membership, but stands alone regarding North Macedonia; in October 2019 when it rejected Albania, the Netherlands and Denmark agreed.  For this reason it seems that North Macedonia has a slightly better chance (barring its upcoming election) than Albania at the moment, but both have decent odds: Germany and Italy are in support, and are putting pressure on the EC to come up with a satisfactory solution to France’s complaints about the membership process.

I think with the UK in the process of leaving the eu family the eu will be keen to bring more friends and allies onto there side especially with the chance that the eu might have more of there fellow eu friends might decide they want to start divorce proceeding. Thanks Regards
Easiest solution is to refuse both but should it be in French interests they will prefer both. Allowing one is difficult but North Macedonia may be felt to be more deserving.

An excellent overview by @bbrandreth, however, I reach a very different conclusion. This is not the year.
Key dates to revise my forecast using data provided above would be Feb 25 and March 27.

- The Western Balkans are now less relevant and attractive for EU economies.
- The EU is currently prioritising stability and a pro-Western orientation of its near abroad rather than democracy promotion.
- Public support for EU enlargement in member states has eroded over time, and populist parties have instrumentalised opposition to enlargement. France has introduced the requirement of a national referendum for future accessions, and given Marcon's vulnerbility on the domestic front it is highly unlikely he will pursue an enlargement policy - not least when there are other prirorities to manage - eg the EU's budget woes.

The EU's largest dissuader for growing the block, Macron, has relaxed his view point recently. It seems that more EU members are now for such a deal than against. Negotiations do not have to formally take place, just a decision made in favor of them, making the timeline for this to happen more realistic.

The arguments against are the distraction of Brexit and what that implies for the EU's inability to balance its books, and further accessions of net recipient states would strain the budget.   Macron is a major factor, but it sounds like his opposition is waning and he might agree to opening negotiations as they can always simply run and lead nowhere until necessary reforms are actually undertaken, and even being in negotiations might keep both states out of the ambit of Russia / Turkey / China.  He has made his point as regards reforms being necessary before accession itself (not negotiations).  Plus if he is going to be the motor of Brexit friction does he also want to pick this fight?  Politically he has probably already gained all the points he'll gain. Merkel will likely push hard as part of her legacy / swansong.  Will Macron want to rain on her barbecue when negotiations don't need to lead to anything? Also more likely in order to bolster pro-EU politicians in both countries against nationalist populists.  Macron might well feel his resistance, leading to resignation of North Macedonian Europhile PM, was a pyrrhic victory at best and might now be looking for a ladder to climb down. Will look to revise after March report.

The primary but not sole obstacle is France, which has explicitly linked the two countries' fates. The French stated position is not just about Albania and North Macedonia but also about the process: "This is a dispute about vision," he said. "The enlargement rules need reform. We mustn't open accession talks with North Macedonia before Albania - there must be a majority for talks with both, together. We should do more to help those countries develop, not just make pledges."
 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-50100201 and https://www.politico.eu/article/france-outlines-proposal-to-overhaul-eu-accession-process/ Resolving French concerns would require focus from the EU in a year when it must also engage in negotiations with the UK over future relations. It would also require concerted effort from Germany to overcome French concerns and it is not clear that Germany's politicians currently have capacity to think creatively about non-domestic politics. But... "However, there may have been the necessary progress - The European Commission recently submitted a stricter and reversible EU accession procedure to meet the conditions set by France ahead of a summit on the Balkans in May.
Paris is also awaiting a report on the reality of the reforms requested by France, the Netherlands and Denmark. The subject is to be discussed by the 27 EU countries on February 25 during a meeting EU EU ministers in Brussels."
https://www.euronews.com/2020/02/15/macron-hints-at-progress-on-eu-enlargement-for-albania-and-north-macedonia 25 February key date for review of probability! "The Commission's proposals are likely to soften the reservations of France, the Netherlands and Denmark.
French Deputy Minister for European Affairs Amélie de Montchalin reported "very good discussions with Commissioner Várhelyi" during a press briefing in Brussels on Tuesday.
"France is asking for a gradual, concrete process which brings benefits on the ground. A reversible process, and a process which is politically steered. I think that the communications on Wednesday (by the Commission) will show that we have in all these areas a change of methodology, of paradigm, "she said.
Yet she warned that France won't automatically agree to open negotiations with Skopje and Tirana.
"We have to make sure, on the basis of the situation report that the Commission will present in March, that the conditions are met," she said.
The European Commission is due to publish in March an individual report for each of the six Western Balkan countries applying for membership - Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Serbia - on the state of the reforms carried out, respect for the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and fundamental rights."
https://www.euronews.com/2020/02/05/eu-commission-presents-new-enlargement-strategy-amid-divisions-over-albania-and-north-mace "French President Emmanuel Macon, who blocked the opening of talks with Skopje and Tirana in October, said at the weekend he was willing to allow them to begin membership talks if the European Commission gave them a positive review next month....
"Denmark and the Netherlands, who supported Macron, are expected to drop their resistance, EU diplomats told Reuters."
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-balkans/north-macedonia-albania-will-deliver-eu-enlargement-chief-says-idUSKBN20C1GC 26-27 March second key date for review of probability. Note dates of European meetings suggest if the answer is no in May 2020 (EU Summit with Western Balkans countries in Croatia in May https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/international-summit/2020/05/05-07/)

After Brexit the Union will be focused not on enlargment, but on cohesion. Albania and North Macedonia would aggravate some of the concerns of intra-union migration in CEE and would not be endorsed by Hungary.
Unanimous decision needed and some countries unlikely to agree

Angela Merkel is the most influential leader in the EU, and she vocally opposes Russian attempts to increase influence over Eastern Europe. Because she will step down no later than 2021, I do not believe there will be enough European leaders willing to go along with her in bringing Albania and North Macedonia into the EU.  Additionally, the rise of far-right, anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim influences in France, Hungary, Germany, and Poland means that there may be attempts to prevent Muslim-majority Albania from joining purely on that count.
Unlikely that given the issues that the EU is facing this year that they would consider increasing membership.

With regards to the enlargement of the European Union to include North Macedonia as well as Albania, I think it is unlikely that the ascension talks will begin before October 2020. This is because the European Union is still reeling with the after-effects of Brexit. However, on the other hand, French President Emmanual Macron has teased about opening up ascension talks saying that France will lift its veto of ascension talks to join the European Union for both countries. I doubt however that it will be before October 2020 though.

France is dropping objections and process has been tightened. These countries are spoken if in same breath but if you look at activities needed Albania is ahead. A report comes out on February 28 that will be important to decide to move ahead or not. Readjust then. https://www.euronews.com/2020/02/15/macron-hints-at-progress-on-eu-enlargement-for-albania-and-north-macedonia
https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_20_181

- The EU commission and Germany are pro-accession talks starting asap. 
- The President of the European Commission, von der Leyen, will be keen to be seen making an impact early on in her tenure.
- EU's enlargement chief, Oliver Varhelyi, made positive remarks on 18/02/2020 regarding the reforms that need to be made in NM and Albania in order for talks to begin.
- The main opposition has come from France. But this opposition has mainly been routed in the procedural mechanisms required for accession talks to begin. The Commission has stated that these are to be reformed. Macron has since softened his tone.
- Macron wanting to burnish his EU credentials as Merkel departs both will want to be seen as moving accession talks forward. Desire for positive coverage of EU membership after Brexit withdrawal talks have been all consuming in terms of the narrative. 
- Fears in EU and European capitals that further delay will lead to greater Russian and/or Chinese influence in these states. Greater desire for the EU to be more assertive in foreign policy matters (e.g. EU defence cooperation). 
- Talks take many years. Agreement to begin them is NOT the same as allowing NM and/or Albania to join the EU imminently.

It is a controversial move, yet the odd chance is that the talks will start because there is a lot to win for these countries, while most of the European public isn't that actively opposed to new member states.

short timeframe. Base rate isn't positive here. When you think about it, this is almost 27 different forecasts rolled into one, because all 27 EU states have to agree to start accession negotiations (which would explain why so many of these EU questions resolve in the negative).

France and Germany are preparing a big negotiation on the future of the EU. The accession talks will be part of the bargain. Albania will be sacrificed to let France save face in front of it's voters.

After years of delay, the EU will look to seize the initiative and reassert its authority after years of muddling through Brexit. They will look for positive coverage of the benefits of EU membership and will open negotiations with both countries.

The EU is in a state of flux post Brexit. Previously quietly Eurosceptic countries (Netherlands, scandinavian nations) will start to assert themselves more. Having previously hidden objections behind the UK.  If accession talks begin, it will be for both countries. If only one country, North Macedonia already went through the humiliating name change process and is a marginally smaller pop.

Both countries have been candidates for a significant period of time (as long or longer than most other countries, historically (though North Macedonia has an extra 5 years or so on Albania).  The EU has given unconditional recommendation to both, and has said they'll address enlargement in May 2020.
Neither side will be able to afford it
The EU wants to secure its presence in Muslim-majority Albania and N. Macedonia, which also has a strong presence of Muslim Albanians.

Domestic political instability in both France and Germany will divert focus away from EU issues. France, Denmark and Holland will continue to hold out and block talks. The EU will wait until the conclusion of the agreed transition period due to the UK leaving the bloc on 31st January before they open official assession talks with N. Macedonia and Albania in early 2021.

Macron is clearly against the idea, - which makes sense since Macron's Renew Europe group stands to gain nothing, other than becoming more diluted in a Europe with more EPP (North Macedonia) and S&D (Albania) members both in Parliament and in the Council. Because all countries need to approve, Macron's veto is enough for the talks to never go anywhere, - he may eventually give in to pressure from others in the EU who fear that these countries will stray from European values and interests, but I think countries like Finland and others that want to cut on EU spending can also stop it from happening. In March, if there's a positive report on these countries, then the chances of (any) yes do increase.
Someday perhaps, but the timeframe is just too short and the EU lacks leadership in the short term for expansion.

Albania has been a member of NATO for just over ten years and hasn't yet managed to crack the EU club. North Macedonia is on the verge of joining NATO (will be the 29th member, first new member in a while; after Albania and Croatia in 2009, there's only been Montenegro in 2017). The last new members in the EU were Bulgaria and Romania in 2007, which is a long time ago. Getting a former Balkan nation into the fold is a big ask. I think the chances are lower than what I've guessed.
Neither France nor Germany have the political stomach to expand membership of net recipient countries now.

Lead by France the E.U. will direct its attention to internal reform before expanding.  Germany which might champion the talks is in political disarray.  There is also the need to negotiate the new trade pack with the U.K.
France and Germany cannot resolve their disagreements on this topic

This is about immigration (human right, rule of law and economic policy also mentioned). Previously Macron tried to tie Albanian and North Macedonian talks together - recipe for stalling. Merkel would like them to stand individually. Regardless, requires unanimity. Most of Europe wants to proceed.
Both countries ate some way off from meeting entry requirements.

This provides a good overview of the steps that need to take place for these countries to join the EU [1]. Both Albania and North Macedonia have proposed candidacy, but membership negotiations (accession negotiations) cannot begin until all EU governments agree. France's does not public declare opposition to specific countries, they just seem to not want to grant access at all. Given how long this process takes from negotiations to becoming a member, I think France will not want to take too great a hit surrounding this. However, the EU is somewhat fragile, so there may be general pushback. However, I think either both get moved to negotiations or neither. None of the push-back seems particular to one country. Brexit sucking too much air out, EU needs more net positive economic contributors after UK leaves. Only not 100% because there is a need to fill the void and block Russia.

The EU has too much on its plate right now, particularly with the need to negotiate the post-Brexit agreement with the UK, and the turmoil in Germany, to begin such negotiations.  Brexit, and the increasing nationalist movements throughout Europe will require the EU to rethink its long-term approach to things before letting new nations join.
